monogr.title: The holy sinner : a tractate meditated on some passages of the storie of the penitent woman in the Pharisees house. by [sic] W.H
monogr.author: Hodson, William

div.head: A proeme to the Reader.
div.p:
AS no beauty, so no book hath all voices: even in the worst some eyes see features that please; in the best, some others see lines that they like not:
Pro captu lectoris habent sua fata libelli.
Mart.
Some out of affection may plat a laurel for that head, on which others, in their opinion, would bestow the thistle. This little tractate hath already passed through private hands, and found (but what allay is friendship unto censure?) a candid interpretation. And divers copies were presented to
me, to usher forth my book But I am not ambition to hang the ivie garland at my doore: I have purposely reserved them for a close, lest I should seem, like an Italian host, to meet my guest upon the way, and to promise beforehand a fair and ample entertainment. Let it please you rather to see and allow your cheer; and then according to your own palate, you may disgust, or rellish the cookerie.
